content: How can I help you today?

I guess I’ve just been really overwhelmed. Things at home have been really hard with my son’s behavior, and it’s affecting everything else—my marriage, work, even just enjoying life. I don’t know where to start.

That sounds like a lot to be carrying all at once. Feeling overwhelmed and pulled in so many directions—especially when it affects the people you love and your own well-being—is really hard. What’s been the hardest part for you in all of this?

Honestly, the hardest part is feeling like I’m failing my family. My son’s behavior is so out of control, and I don’t know how to help him. It’s driving a wedge between my wife and me, and I feel like I’m letting everyone down, including myself.

It sounds like you're carrying a deep sense of responsibility for your family's well-being, and feeling like you're not meeting expectations is weighing heavily on you. It’s clear how much you care about your son, your wife, and your family, and how much you want things to be better for everyone. What helps you to get through moments like this, even just a little?

I honestly don't know right now. I feel like I've just been pushing through, but there's nothing that really helps. Even the things I used to enjoy don't bring me any relief anymore. Everything just feels so heavy all the time.

That heaviness sounds exhausting, especially when nothing feels like it offers even a small break. It must be frustrating to lose connection with the things that once brought you joy. What matters most to you right now, even through all of this?
Keeping my family together, I guess. I feel like everything is falling apart, but I really want to help my son and be there for my wife and daughter. I just don’t know how to fix any of it.

Your commitment to keeping your family together really stands out, even while you’re feeling lost in how to make that happen. That shows such strength and care, even in the middle of such a heavy time. What have you noticed about what your son might be struggling with, or what your wife and daughter need most right now?

My son has been acting out a lot, and it feels like he's struggling with something, but I can’t figure out what. My wife is clearly stressed and frustrated about it too, and we just keep clashing instead of working together. As for my daughter, I feel like she’s being forgotten in all this, and that hurts me too because she deserves more attention from me. I feel like I'm falling short for all of them.

You’re seeing the challenges each person in your family is facing, and it’s clear how much you care about all of them. Feeling like you’re stretched too thin and unsure how to support everyone must be overwhelming. You already have such a deep awareness of what’s happening. What would it mean to you if you could find even one small step toward improving things for your family?
I guess it would mean some hope, like maybe things don’t have to fall apart completely. I just don’t know where to even begin—it feels like too much to handle all at once.

Holding onto hope, even in the middle of all this, speaks to how much you want things to get better. The idea of taking on everything at once feels like an impossible weight to manage, but maybe starting somewhere small could bring relief or momentum. Is there anything you’ve thought about doing—or anything that feels manageable—that could be a step in the right direction?

I haven’t really thought about a specific step. Maybe trying to communicate better with my wife or figuring out how to get some help for my son? But even thinking about those feels overwhelming right now.

It makes sense that even thinking about taking action feels overwhelming when you’re already carrying so much. Focusing on communication with your wife or exploring support for your son could be meaningful steps, but it doesn’t have to happen all at once. It’s okay to take things slowly. What do you think might help make one of those feel a little less overwhelming?

Maybe if my wife and I could sit down and calmly talk without arguing, that would help. But lately, it feels like every conversation turns into a fight, and I don’t know how to break that cycle. Maybe some kind of outside help, like support for us as parents, could make it easier, but I’m not sure.

Finding a way to break the cycle of arguments and communicate calmly with your wife sounds really important to you, especially as a step toward working together instead of feeling disconnected. Reaching out for outside support as parents could provide guidance and help ease some of the pressure you’re both facing. It’s understandable to feel unsure about where to start, but even thinking about these ideas reflects your commitment to making a change. Would you want to explore what seeking that kind of support might look like?

I’m not sure about it, to be honest. I mean, I’ve never really asked for outside help before, and it feels a little intimidating. But if it could actually help us work together and understand everything better, maybe it’s worth thinking about. I just don’t know how to even begin that process.

It’s completely normal to feel intimidated about seeking help, especially when it’s something new for you. The fact that you’re open to thinking about it shows courage and a real commitment to improving things for your family. It could be a way to gain tools for working together and understanding what your son or your family as a whole might need. Would it help to take some time to explore your thoughts about the idea or talk through what steps might feel manageable for starting that process?
I think I am okay to end the conversation. Thank you for speaking about this with me.
